chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise requires us to differentiate marginal and average tax rates. We will also explain the impact of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 on corporate tax rates.

**Taxes** are significant expenses that a taxable individual or entity may incur. A large portion of income goes to payment of tax expenses which government will then use for **funding projects** such as healthcare, infrastructure, security, and other social welfare projects.

### 2.3a - Difference between average and marginal tax rate.

The portion of income allocated to taxes refers to the **average tax rate**. Shown below is the computation related to this rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Average tax rate} &= \dfrac{\text{Tax bill}}{\text{Taxable income}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The tax bill is divided by the taxable income to arrive at the average tax rate.

On the other hand, **marginal tax rate** refers to the tax rate that would apply should an entity or an individual would earn one more dollar. For instance, a firm with a 35% marginal tax rate would pay $0.35 for every dollar of income earned. Thus, financial managers consider marginal tax rates because any additional revenues earned by an entity will affect overall profitability.

### 2.3b - Impact of Tax Cuts and Job Acts of 2017.

The passage of Tax Cuts and Job Acts of 2017 poses many criticisms in Trump's presidency. Many government officials stated that the vast cut in tax rates would cause deficits in government funding and may decrease the budgets allotted for fiscal expenditures.

Business-wise, the enactment of the Tax Cuts and Job Acts of 2017 led to cost savings for many entities. Corporate taxes changed into a flat **21%**, enabling many corporations to save from lower tax bills.

As entities consider taxes one of their **primary sources of cash outflows**, managers must understand tax codes and laws that may affect their financial decisions. It would keep businesses adherent with government taxation policies by **reducing tax filings and payments errors**.
This exercise requires us to determine the e impact of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 on corporate tax rates

Let's first define the Tax cuts and Jobs Act of 2017.

The **Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017** is a United States congressional revenue act signed into law by President Donald Trump that lowers business tax rates, increases the standard deduction and family tax credits, and reduces the alternative minimum tax, among other things.

The impact of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 is it reduces the top corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21%, bringing the US rate below average and eliminating the graduated corporate rate schedule.
